abstract.p: After the Eastern Japan Great Earthquake, the tsunami and the nuclear fallout of Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, now known as 3.11, writers and intellectuals have felt the urge to express their thoughts on the disaster and the experiences they lived. This paper begins with the words of Haruki Murakami that provide important insight into ancient philosophical thought; it establishes a line of continuity with the tradition of the Japanese Buddhist concept of mujō (impermanence). The paper is an attempt to shed light on this concept in the classical narrative model of the medieval era, the Hōjōki (12th century). The inability to look at the future has prompted many young writers influenced by the trauma of 2011 to deal with the past, becoming aware of the nuclear disaster through the symbolic association of Fukushima/Hiroshima. It is certainly too early to draw a comprehensive map of the literature post-3/11 but it is possible to identify in the narrative, works inspired by the theme of this catastrophe as well as new and never seen characteristics. The example taken here is the short-novel Kamisama 2011, allegedly inspired by the catastrophe of Fukushima. In rewriting the original story (Kamisama), the novelist Kawakami Hiromi reinterprets the classical relationship between man and nature, inspired by the Shinto spirituality and now re-contextualized in a polluted world, where man is a victim of his own action of domination and manipulation of the natural elements. The imagery of the fantastic that gave the impression of an almost innocent, infantile story, now changes the utopia of the harmony between man and nature in a dystopia, a "non-place" of contamination and death that could be everywhere in the world.
